subject: On the Role of Programmer Tests... maybe
msgSnippet: So said  Eric Armstrong  on  2/24/2003 -------------------- ... I ll ... to ... have ... Mostly your run-of-the-mill specification by example stuff. I didn t
messageBody:
So said Eric Armstrong on 2/24/2003 --------------------

>"J. B. Rainsberger" wrote:
>
>> So said Eric Armstrong on 2/21/2003 --------------------
>>
>> >"J. B. Rainsberger" wrote:
>> >
>> >> The goal of Programmer Tests is to for the programmer to:
>> >> * have tangible evidence of progress
>> >> * clarify the needs of the design
>> >> * "eat his own dog food" by being forced to
>> >> write client code before writing provider code
>> >> * keep focus on small steps
>> >> * avoid writing too much code in one flow
>> >>
>> >> ...
>> >> I feel appropriately inspired. Let me write the article, then
I'll
>> be back...
>> >
>>
>> I lost the head of steam, so I don't know when the article's going
to
>> happen. In the next few months, I think.
>
>I was particularly interested in seeing the part on "clarifying the
>needs of the
>design".
>
>What, pray tell, was the unordered list of bullet points you might
have
>put (or will be putting) into that section of the article?

Mostly your run-of-the-mill specification by example stuff. I didn't
mean for that bullet point to come off as grandiose. :)

As often happens, the article I wrote is not the article I intended to
write. I think that it is in the ballpark, but as soon as I introduced
a specific example, I locked in to the example.

Feel free to look at http://24.42.96.247:762/bin/view/Articles. The
article definitely ambles, and I haven't edited it yet. I would be most
grateful to know what points you would have expected such an article to
hit that it does not hit.

Thanks.


J. B. Rainsberger,
President, Diaspar Software Services
Let's write software that people understand.
